page.title: 18DISUSED RAILWAY LOSSIEMOUTH
page.content: In 1852 the Morayshire railway was opened. The track connected Elgin with the Moray coast. The railway line closed for passengers in 1965 and many people were sad. At that time it cost sixpence (two and a half pence) and a shilling (five pence) for an adult. Freight continued for a further eighteen months until 1966. Eight trains a day left Lossiemouth. There was a goods train, passenger trains, a sleeper train and a train which took fish to Aberdeen and Glasgow. Whenever a train left Lossiemouth an old ship's bell was rung. The ship's bell is now kept in the Lossiemouth Fishing Museum. Today the railway line is only used as a footpath.
